audited_claims.strategic_fit_assessment: Scale metric only - doesn't demonstrate business model transformation or AI centrality
audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: Good - named organization, specific numbers, traceable source
audited_claims.notes: Large customer base indicates success but not transformation - this is a scale metric

audited_claims.notes: High acquisition rate shows market success but not business model innovation

audited_claims.notes: Market segment growth indicates effective targeting but not fundamental business model change

audited_claims.strategic_fit_assessment: Scale and acquisition efficiency metrics - impressive but not transformational
audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: Good - specific numbers, though user count conflicts with C1 (115M vs 54M)
audited_claims.notes: Word-of-mouth growth shows strong product-market fit but doesn't demonstrate new value creation model

audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: Good - specific NPS score with competitive comparison
audited_claims.notes: High NPS indicates superior execution but not business model innovation

audited_claims.evidence_quality_assessment: Good - specific CAC figures across multiple years
audited_claims.notes: Low CAC shows operational efficiency but represents optimization, not transformation

audited_claims.notes: High activity rate shows strong user engagement but doesn't demonstrate business model change

tier_verification: This case appears to be misclassified as tier 1. All claims describe operational excellence, efficiency improvements, and scale achievements within a traditional digital banking model. While Nubank executes exceptionally well, there's no evidence of business model transformation, new market creation, or AI as a core value driver. This should be classified as tier 1 (optimization) rather than tier 1 (transformation). The 'remove the AI' test: if you removed AI/ML from Nubank, you'd still have a digital bank - just less efficient. The core banking model remains unchanged.
